repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This avoids running into Python's limits about the maximum number of digits to use in string conversion.

Fixes #5596

I suspect this isn't *everywhere* that could generate long number strings but it's sufficient to solve the reported bug.

comment_data.body: I've taken the view that it isn't a huge problem if a few variables have different names when run with Python 2 so just disabled the test
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -473,7 +473,10 @@ def get_openmp_compiler_flags(language):
                                            'run.unicode_imports',  # encoding problems on appveyor in Py2
                                            'run.reimport_failure',  # reimports don't do anything in Py2
                                            'run.cpp_stl_cmath_cpp17',
-                                           'run.cpp_stl_cmath_cpp20'
+                                           'run.cpp_stl_cmath_cpp20',
+                                           'run.large_integer_T5290',  # Py2 adds an L at the end of

comment_data.body: Seeing this, what would you think about requiring that the hex string must be shorter than the decimal string in order to replace it? That way, we'd get normal looking decimal strings for anything that users would want to look at, and hex strings for anything that's long enough to merit representing in hex. (This would also merit being a helper function.)
This seems worth a helper function. It'd also be easier to remove again in Cython 3.1. A really bad name would be `delpy2`. :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4473,9 +4473,13 @@ def visit_BinopNode(self, node):
                        getattr(operand2, 'unsigned', '')
             longness = "LL"[:max(len(getattr(operand1, 'longness', '')),
                                  len(getattr(operand2, 'longness', '')))]
+            value = hex(int(node.constant_result))
+            if value[-1] in 'lL':
+                # Python 2 fix
+                value = value[:-1]

comment_data.body: This could probably stay enabled if we used the same "strip suffix in Py2" helper function to build the names.

comment_data.body: Yes - I'm pretty sure this should work now actually so I'll re-enable it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -473,7 +473,10 @@ def get_openmp_compiler_flags(language):
                                            'run.unicode_imports',  # encoding problems on appveyor in Py2
                                            'run.reimport_failure',  # reimports don't do anything in Py2

-                                           'run.cpp_stl_cmath_cpp20'
+                                           'run.cpp_stl_cmath_cpp20',
+                                           'run.large_integer_T5290',  # Py2 adds an L at the end of

comment_data.body:
The equal crossover is about 1,000,000 and the greater than point is about `10**13`. I'll change the `2**64` to `10**13` - that seems about right. There's only actually one point that affects code generation so I don't think it needs to be a helper function.

What I think is worthwhile is adding `hex_value` and `base_10_value` properties to `IntNode` just for the sake of these tests (and not worry about the string length in those). It'd make the tests more reliable to have a known consistent representation available.
`l` is easy to confuse with `1` and `I` in many fonts, especially `1` in the context of numbers. Maybe `strip_py2_long_suffix`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -454,6 +455,16 @@ def str_to_number(value):
     return -value if is_neg else value
 
 
+def strip_l_py2(value_str):

comment_data.body: Can use the utility function here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1436,7 +1446,15 @@ def coerce_to_boolean(self, env):
     def generate_evaluation_code(self, code):
         if self.type.is_pyobject:
             # pre-allocate a Python version of the number
-            plain_integer_string = str(Utils.str_to_number(self.value))
+            # (In hex if sufficiently large to cope with Python's string-to-int limitations.
+            #  We use quite a small value of "sufficiently large" - 10**13 is picked as
+            #  the approximate point where hex strings become shorter)
+            value = Utils.str_to_number(self.value)
+            formatter = hex if value > (10**13) else str
+            plain_integer_string = formatter(value)
+            if plain_integer_string[-1] in 'lL':
+                # Python 2 fix...
+                plain_integer_string = plain_integer_string[:-1]

commit.message:
Use hex to store large integers

This avoids running into Python's limits about the maximum
number of digits to use in string conversion.

Fixes #5596

I suspect this isn't *everywhere* that could generate long number
strings but it's sufficient to solve the reported bug.
Skip test in Py2 (names are slightly different)
More consistently drop trailing Ls for Py2

Revert "Skip test in Py2 (names are slightly different)"

This reverts commit d303d84bda0812f1eff58923a4dbf6ab25d44554.

title: Use hex to store large integers
